awd_abstract_narration:
PI: Sah, Robert L. 
Proposal Number: 1721922

NSF has made an award to support registration fees for 54 graduate and undergraduate students to attend the four-day TERMIS-AM meeting, held in San Diego, CA from December 11-14, 2016. The conference, organized as the annual Americas meeting of the Tissue Engineering and Regenerative Medicine International Society (TERMIS), brings together researchers from biomedical science, biomedical engineering, and manufacturing engineering from throughout the western hemisphere to present the latest research.  Focus on the outcome rather than on the discipline supports cross-disciplinary conversations and the development of interdisciplinary collaborations.  The theme of this year's workshop is "Personalized and Precise Science, Engineering, and Translation".  Sessions include a focus on cellular reprogramming, vascularization, drug delivery, organoids for in vitro screening, biomaterials, manufacturing, and applications of tissue engineering.  Special sessions to support the professional development of trainees have been included to support the development of networks and identification of varied career opportunities.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
This award supported students primarily to attend the 2016 Tissue Engineering and Regenerative Medicine International Society - Americas Chapter (TERMIS-AM) Annual Meeting.

The theme for the 2016 TERMIS-AM Meeting was "Personalized and Precise Science, Engineering, and Translation." The meeting reflected advancements in Tissue Engineering (TE) and Regenerative Medicine (RM) toward becoming disciplines that are increasingly sophisticated, targeted toward individuals, and impactful on society. A vibrant scientific program of the 2016 TERMIS-AM Meeting reflected input from a Scientific Advisory Committee, twelve TERMIS-AM Thematic Working Interest Groups (TWIGs), the TERMIS-AM Student and Young Investigator Section (SYIS), Women in TERM, and proposed symposia. Keynote presentations and symposia addressed cellular reprogramming, organoids for in vitro screening, enabling biomaterials, stem cells, multi-scale tissue engineering including microfabrication, and 3D printing, and a variety of applications. 

The 2016 TERMIS-AM meeting had a broad impact. Academia, Industry, Practicing Physicians, and Government were all actively involved in planning, presenting at, and/or sponsoring the meeting. Government participants included Federal institutions, the FDA, NIST, and NSF, as well as the California Institute for Regenerative Medicine. The keynote speakers and events fostered a diverse and inclusive community with major representation by women and under-represented groups. A Women in TERM luncheon highlighted successful biotechnology entrepreneurship. In addition, resources available in the San Diego, CA area allowed a visit to the Sanford Consortium for Regenerative Medicine Building, in which a multi-disciplinary and collaborative community of scientists strive to use stem cells for treatment and cure of human diseases. 

This award supported a total of 52 students, most (39) at the 2016 TERMIS-AM meeting and some (13) at the 2017 TERMIS-AM meeting. These students directly participated in interactive and networking sessions, including poster and career panel discussions, and a student-meet-mentor luncheon. In addition, many of these students amplified their participation indirectly, by reporting on the meeting to peers at their colleges and universities.

 


Last Modified: 04/11/2024
Modified by: Robert L Sah
